unnormalised: New Delhi, October 26 - Automotive Research Association of India (ARAI) reports significant strides in fuel efficiency across various vehicle segments. Dr. Meena Iyer, lead researcher at ARAI, stated that average fuel economy has improved by 15% in passenger vehicles over the last 5 years, driven by advancements in engine technology and lightweight materials.
normalised: New Delhi, October twenty six - Automotive Research Association of India (A R A I) reports significant strides in fuel efficiency across various vehicle segments. Doctor Meena Iyer, lead researcher at A R A I, stated that average fuel economy has improved by fifteen percent in passenger vehicles over the last five years, driven by advancements in engine technology and lightweight materials.

unnormalised: The report highlights Maruti Suzuki's Alto 800 leading the pack in the entry-level segment with a claimed mileage of 22.05 kmpl. Electric vehicle (EV) adoption is also contributing positively, with Tata Nexon EV showing impressive range figures.
normalised: The report highlights Maruti Suzuki's Alto eight hundred leading the pack in the entry-level segment with a claimed mileage of twenty two point zero five kilometer per liter. Electric vehicle (E V) adoption is also contributing positively, with Tata Nexon E V showing impressive range figures.

unnormalised: However, experts caution that real-world conditions in cities like Mumbai, with heavy traffic and stop-and-go driving, can significantly impact these numbers. They advise regular vehicle maintenance and eco-driving habits to maximize fuel savings. Moreover, the rising fuel prices (Rs. 106/litre) are encouraging consumers to prioritize fuel efficiency, impacting buying decisions. Consumers are also looking into alternate fuel sources like CNG to cut costs. A recent survey indicated that buyers in metropolitan cities are even willing to compromise on car size (reducing parking footprint from say 150 sq ft to 120 sq ft) to achieve better mileage.
